item.title: AsciiDoc to GitHub
item.description: Tracking changes online GitHub is a tool for sharing text. Most of that text is code, but it can also work for sharing legislation. It is a familiar tool for programmers, making it easy to track changes to code over time, and to talk about what changes make sense. Those are natural advantages for legislation as well as code.

item.title: XML to AsciiDoc
item.description: A format to make legislation readable… …For computers The AsciiDoc format is plain text with some simple markup. Using plain text makes it easy to track changes, and do other transformations, with tools familiar to most programmers. …For people Raw AsciiDoc is still pretty readable for people. That means the automatic comparison of “what changed” is more useful than with raw XML. AsciiDoc also renders to look like a formatted web page, so the text is still approachable for non-technical users.

item.title: About
item.description: Law as Code As part of the Better Rules Hackathon, we wanted to help make legislation easier to use, track, and improve. The Goal We wanted to build a proof-of-concept, to show that it is both feasible and beneficial to make legislation easier to work with. The Approach We wanted to use simple, familiar tools, to make the most of our limited time over the weekend. We chose to push our output to GitHub, a popular platform for sharing and working with code, to avoid any need to manage our own web hosting.
